sentence: As per sources, Lumber Liquidators Holdings, Inc.LL has a been slapped with a $5 million class action lawsuit, filed in Florida, after a 60 Minutes report accused the company of selling toxic flooring products.
Following the news, shares of the company fell over 5% in yesterday's trading session.

Moreover, as per sources, a democrat senator, Bill Nelson has wrote to three federal agencies, Consumer Product Safety Commission, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Federal Trade Commission, demanding a thorough probe into the matter.
On Mar 1, 2015, 60 Minutes reported that Lumber Liquidators has been selling laminates that do not meet formaldehyde levels permitted by the California emissions standards.
Formaldehyde is a powerful carcinogen that causes myeloid leukemia and other various cancers and is also known to cause respiratory problems.
The news agency had conducted an undercover operation at the company's Chinese factory, where a group of reporters with hidden cameras interacted with the workers.
The Chinese workers said that though the formaldehyde levels were high, the laminates were marked as compliant with the California standards.
Since the report surfaced, Lumber Liquidators shares have lost nearly 35% of their market value.
However, Lumber Liquidators continues to vehemently deny all the charges and has blamed the whole thing on short sellers.
The company stated that it will never sell unsafe products to customers for boosting revenues.
Moreover, the company mentioned it will address its investors for a business update on Mar 12, but will not be a part of the Raymond James' Annual Institutional Investors Conference.
This assurance, however, has failed to pacify investors and environmentalists alike and the company is likely to face further significant challenges on the legal front.
The controversy could not have come at a worst time for Lumber Liquidators.
The company's performance over the last year has been nothing short of dismal with the results missing the Zacks Consensus Estimate in the trailing four quarters by an average of 12.9%.
In the most recent quarter, earnings per share of 64 cents not only plunged 13.5% year over year but also came way below the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 76 cents.
Though net sales climbed 5.2% year over year to $272 million, it fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $280 million.

This Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) company, which is dominating the headlines for the wrong reasons, is unlikely to benefit from home improvement projects that may increase on account of boost in disposable income following lower gasoline prices and an improving job scenario.
Consequently, analysts have become less constructive about the stock's performance as sales for the first quarter of fiscal 2015 are expected to bear of the brunt.
This was reflected in a downward revision in the Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter over the past 7 days.
It seems that Lumber Liquidators' troubles might spell gain for other home improvement retailer's such as Lowe's Companies Inc. LOW , The Home Depot, Inc. HD and Tile Shop Holdings, Inc. TTS .
